metadata.title: Custom handling of target tap URLs

sections.title: Custom handling of target tap URLs

inlineContent.text: Sometimes you need to handle taps in your own way. For example, to display ads in the internal browser in the app. In this tutorial, we will learn how to customise the SDK’s tap handling behaviour.
We will continue to build the app, so be sure to follow all the previous tutorials. You can download
which has already implemented all steps from this tutorial.

sections.chapter: Extending the SDK with your custom advertisements

inlineContent.text: In this section, we will create a screen with a browser that will display the target URL when you click on an ad.

in the
path. In this file, we will implement the URL processing logic.
The first step is to create a URL wrapper that confirms to the
protocol.
Next, we create a
with a block that we will later call every time we want to present an URL in our browser.
Now let’s open the
file.

The last step is to add a presentation logic. To do this, open the

We add the logic to show the

In this section, we will look at how you can implement custom target URL processing.
Let’s return to the
file we created earlier.
The SDK provides a
interface designed to handle target URLs, which you can implement.
It has two methods, one of which is optional, so let’s start with it.
will be called every time the SDK wants to validate the target URL. If you return
, the SDK will throw an
error.
If you do not implement this method, all URLs will be considered valid.
The second method is mandatory. The
will be called every time the SDK wants the URL to be opened for the user. In our case, we want to call the
block.
All we have to do is somehow pass this object to the SDK. To do this, open the
file.
As you may have noticed,
has a
parameter to which we can pass our object. Let’s do that. Now, if you launch the app and tap on the ad, you can see that the target URL opens in the internal browser. Congratulations!
